unnormalised: The summer of ‘23 was supposed to be different. After months of working from home, staring at the same four walls in my Gurgaon apartment, I decided I needed an escape. A proper getaway. So, I booked a trip to Kerala. Kochi, specifically. Little did I know, securing that escape would involve more ID juggling than I anticipated.
normalised: The summer of twenty twenty three was supposed to be different. After months of working from home, staring at the same four walls in my Gurgaon apartment, I decided I needed an escape. A proper getaway. So, I booked a trip to Kerala. Kochi, specifically. Little did I know, securing that escape would involve more I-D juggling than I anticipated.

unnormalised: First, the flight. I managed to snag a decent deal on Indigo, but the booking process itself was a minor ordeal. Inputting my PNR (Passenger Name Record) - 6E-J9K2L - felt like unlocking a secret code. Then came the constant reminders: "Remember your flight details! Keep your Aadhaar card handy!" As if I could forget.
normalised: First, the flight. I managed to snag a decent deal on Indigo, but the booking process itself was a minor ordeal. Inputting my P-N-R (Passenger Name Record) - six E hyphen J nine K two L - felt like unlocking a secret code. Then came the constant reminders: "Remember your flight details! Keep your Aadhaar card handy!" As if I could forget.

unnormalised: Next, the train journey from Ernakulam to Alleppey for the backwaters. Sleeper class, because I’m all about the ‘authentic’ experience. But getting a confirmed ticket proved to be a Herculean task. The IRCTC website, bless its buggy heart, demanded my PNR again. This time a 10-digit number: 4829374650. Finally, success! But the confirmation SMS included a cryptic ‘Coach S3, Seat 72’ and a reference to ‘PNR Status Confirmed: CNF/B4/34.’ Deciphering that took some frantic Googling.
normalised: Next, the train journey from Ernakulam to Alleppey for the backwaters. Sleeper class, because I’m all about the ‘authentic’ experience. This time a ten digit number: forty eight billion two hundred ninety three million seven hundred forty six thousand five hundred. Finally, success! But the confirmation S-M-S included a cryptic ‘Coach S three, Seat seventy two’ and a reference to ‘P-N-R Status Confirmed: C-N-F slash B four slash thirty four.’ Deciphering that took some frantic Googling.

unnormalised: The boat ride through the backwaters was bliss, though. Serene, green, and utterly peaceful. Until, of course, I realized I’d left my wallet back at the hotel in Kochi. Panic set in. How would I prove my identity if needed? My passport, No. Z456789, was safe at the hotel, but what about something local? My driving license, DL No. UP7920100004836? Nope, forgotten.

unnormalised: Luckily, I managed to explain my predicament, and the boat operator, a kind man named Rajesh, accepted a digital copy of my Aadhaar card, saved on my phone. Lesson learned: always have a backup. And maybe invest in a better wallet.

unnormalised: The trip was ultimately amazing, despite the initial ID-induced stress. But it did highlight just how reliant we are on these identifiers. Flight PNRs, train ticket confirmations, Aadhaar numbers – they’re the keys to unlocking experiences, both smooth and slightly chaotic. And sometimes, the chaos makes for the best stories.
